pages.text: Aeger is a genus of Malacostracan crustacean that lived between the late Triassic and the Cretaceous of Europe. This 8 centimeters long animal resembled a modern day prawn both in shape and behavior, preying on small coastal water animals.
It possessed long antennae and three pairs of clawed appendages, all topped with a fairly long abdomen.

Aeger was especially common in Europe's coastal waters, with a plentiful fossil record in areas of Bavaria like the famous Solnhofen, the same area that yielded the world renowned Archaeopteryx lithographica fossil but he's also found in abundance in Osteno, Italy.
